Hainich.formula: sla * (N - sla * R - slb) / (sla * N + R - sla * slb + 0.08 * (1 + sla ** 2.0))

Hainich.long_name: Automated Water Extraction Index with Shadows Elimination
Burned Area Index adapted to MODIS
Blue Wide Dynamic Range Vegetation Index

Hainich.formula: ((lambdaN - lambdaR)/(lambdaN - lambdaG)) * G + (1.0 - ((lambdaN - lambdaR)/(lambdaN - lambdaG))) * N - R

Hainich.long_name: Green Optimized Soil Adjusted Vegetation Index
Modified Chlorophyll Absorption in Reflectance Index
Modified Chlorophyll Absorption in Reflectance Index 1
Modified Chlorophyll Absorption in Reflectance Index 2
Modified Chlorophyll Absorption in Reflectance Index (705 and 750 nm)
Modified Land Surface Water Index (MODIS Bands 2 and 6)
Modified Land Surface Water Index (MODIS Bands 2 and 7)
Non-Binary Snow Index for Multi-Component Surfaces

Hainich.formula: (((lambdaN - lambdaR)/(lambdaN - lambdaG)) * G + (1.0 - ((lambdaN - lambdaR)/(lambdaN - lambdaG))) * N - R)/(((lambdaN - lambdaR)/(lambdaN - lambdaG)) * G + (1.0 - ((lambdaN - lambdaR)/(lambdaN - lambdaG))) * N + R)

Hainich.long_name: Normalized Difference Impervious Surface Index Blue
Normalized Difference Impervious Surface Index Green
Normalized Difference Impervious Surface Index with MNDWI
Normalized Difference Impervious Surface Index with NDWI
Normalized Difference Impervious Surface Index Red

Hainich.formula: (N - (alpha * R + (1.0 - alpha) * S1))/(N + (alpha * R + (1.0 - alpha) * S1))

Hainich.long_name: Normalized Difference Snow Index with no Water
Normalized Difference Snow and Ice Index
Normalized Difference Vegetation Index (705 and 750 nm)
Normalized Difference Water Index with no Snow Cover and Glaciers
Near-Infrared Reflectance of Vegetation and Incoming PAR
Red Edge Normalized Difference Vegetation Index
Soil Adjusted and Atmospherically Resistant Vegetation Index
Transformed Chlorophyll Absorption in Reflectance Index

Hainich.formula: sla * (N - sla * R - slb) / (sla * N + R - sla * slb)
g * (kNN - kNR) / (kNN + C1 * kNR - C2 * kNB + kNL)

esdc-2.1.1-high-res.description: Breathing Earth System Simulator (BESS) is a simplified process-based model that couples atmosphere and canopy radiative transfers, canopy photosynthesis, transpiration, and energy balance. It couples an atmospheric radiative transfer model and artificial neural network with forcings from MODIS atmospheric products to generate 5-km daily products.
esdc-2.1.1-high-res.references: Ryu, Y.*, Jiang, C., Kobayashi, H., & Detto, M. (2018). MODIS-derived global land products of shortwave radiation and diffuse and total photosynthetically active radiation at 5 km resolution from 2000. Remote Sensing of Environment, 204, 812-825

esdc-2.1.1-high-res.description: Breathing Earth System Simulator (BESS) is a simplified process-based model that couples atmosphere and canopy radiative transfers, canopy photosynthesis, transpiration, and energy balance. It couples an atmospheric radiative transfer model and artificial neural network with forcings from MODIS atmospheric products to generate 5-km daily products.

esdc-2.1.1-high-res.description: The 2 m air temperature data ([T2 m]=K) are part of the ERA-Interim reanalysis product and therefore produced by data assimilation techniques in combination with a forecast model. The original spatial sampling (T255 spectral resolution) approximates to 80 km and the original temporal sampling is 6 h for analyses and 3 h for forecasts.
esdc-2.1.1-high-res.references: Dee, D.P., Uppala, S.M., Simmons, A.J., Berrisford, P., Poli, P., Kobayashi, S., Andrae, U., Balmaseda, M.A., Balsamo, G., Bauer, P., Bechtold, P., Beljaars, A.C.M., van de Berg, L., Bidlot, J., Bormann, N., Delsol, C., Dragani, R., Fuentes, M., Geer, A.J., Haimberger, L., Healy, S.B., Hersbach, H., Hólm, E.V., Isaksen, L., Kållberg, P., Köhler, M., Matricardi, M., McNally, A.P., Monge-Sanz, B.M., Morcrette, J.-J., Park, B.-K., Peubey, C., de Rosnay, P., Tavolato, C., Thépaut, J.-N. and Vitart, F. (2011) The ERA-Interim reanalysis: configuration and performance of the data assimilation system. Quarterly Journal of the Royal Meteorological Society, 137, 553–597.

esdc-2.1.1-high-res.description: ERA5 provides hourly estimates of a large number of atmospheric, land and oceanic climate variables. The data cover the Earth on a 30km grid and resolve the atmosphere using 137 levels from the surface up to a height of 80km. ERA5 includes information about uncertainties for all variables at reduced spatial and temporal resolutions.
esdc-2.1.1-high-res.references: Dee, D.P., Uppala, S.M., Simmons, A.J., Berrisford, P., Poli, P., Kobayashi, S., Andrae, U., Balmaseda, M.A., Balsamo, G., Bauer, P., Bechtold, P., Beljaars, A.C.M., van de Berg, L., Bidlot, J., Bormann, N., Delsol, C., Dragani, R., Fuentes, M., Geer, A.J., Haimberger, L., Healy, S.B., Hersbach, H., Hólm, E.V., Isaksen, L., Kållberg, P., Köhler, M., Matricardi, M., McNally, A.P., Monge-Sanz, B.M., Morcrette, J.-J., Park, B.-K., Peubey, C., de Rosnay, P., Tavolato, C., Thépaut, J.-N. and Vitart, F. (2011) The ERA-Interim reanalysis: configuration and performance of the data assimilation system. Quarterly Journal of the Royal Meteorological Society, 137, 553–597.

esdc-2.1.1-high-res.project_name: ESA - Near-real time total ozone column (OMI)
esdc-2.1.1-high-res.long_name: Tropospheric ozone column (based on Fixed Altitude definition)
esdc-2.1.1-high-res.description: The global tropospheric ozone column from 0 to 6 km is presented here. The column is derived by simultaneous assimilating ozone profiles of GOME-2 and OMI.
esdc-2.1.1-high-res.references: Jacob C. A. van Peet, Ronald J. van der A, Hennie M. Kelder, and Pieternel F. Levelt (2018), Simultaneous assimilation of ozone profiles from multiple UV-VIS satellite instruments, Atmospheric Chemistry and Physics, doi:10.5194/acp-18-1685-2018

esdc-2.1.1-high-res.description: The ESA CCI aerosol optical thickness (depth) data sets were created by using algorithms which were developed in the ESA aerosol_cci project. The data used here were created from AATSR measurements (ENVISAT mission) and represent total column AOD at the specified wavelength. Horizontal resolution of the daily data is 1° × 1° on a global grid.
esdc-2.1.1-high-res.references: Holzer-Popp, T., de Leeuw, G., Griesfeller, J., Martynenko, D., Klüser, L., Bevan, S., Davies, W., Ducos, F., Deuzé, J. L., Graigner, R. G., Heckel, A., von Hoyningen-Hüne, W., Kolmonen, P., Litvinov, P., North, P., Poulsen, C. A., Ramon, D., Siddans, R., Sogacheva, L., Tanre, D., Thomas, G. E., Vountas, M., Descloitres, J., Griesfeller, J., Kinne, S., Schulz, M., and Pinnock, S.: Aerosol retrieval experiments in the ESA Aerosol_cci project, Atmos. Meas. Tech., 6, 1919–1957, https://doi.org/10.5194/amt-6-1919-2013, 2013.

esdc-2.1.1-high-res.description: The ESA CCI aerosol optical thickness (depth) data sets were created by using algorithms which were developed in the ESA aerosol_cci project. The data used here were created from Advanced Along-Track Scanning Radiometer (AATSR) measurements (ENVISAT mission) using the algorithm and represent total column AOD at the specified wavelength. Horizontal resolution of the daily data is 1° × 1° on a global grid.
esdc-2.1.1-high-res.references: Holzer-Popp, T., de Leeuw, G., Griesfeller, J., Martynenko, D., Klüser, L., Bevan, S., Davies, W., Ducos, F., Deuzé, J. L., Graigner, R. esdc-2.1.1-high-res.long_name: Chlorophyll-a concentration in seawater generated by SeaDAS
esdc-2.1.1-high-res.description: The ESA Ocean Colour project focuses on the Ocean Colour ECV encompassing water-leaving radiance in the visible domain, derived chlorophyll and inherent optical properties and utilises data archives from Copernicus, ESA, NASA and NOAA.
esdc-2.1.1-high-res.references: Sathyendranath, S.; Grant, M.; Brewin, R.J.W.; Brockmann, C.; Brotas, V.; Chuprin, A.; Doerffer, R.; Dowell, M.; Farman, A.; Groom, S.; Jackson, T.; Krasemann, H.; Lavender, S.; Martinez Vicente, V.; Mazeran, C.; Mélin, F.; Moore, T.S.; Müller, D.; Platt, T.; Regner, P.; Roy, S.; Steinmetz, F.; Swinton, J.; Valente, A.; Zühlke, M.; Antoine, D.; Arnone, R.; Balch, W.M.; Barker, K.; Barlow, R.; Bélanger, S.; Berthon, J.-F.; Beşiktepe, Ş.; Brando, V.E.; Canuti, E.; Chavez, F.; Claustre, H.; Crout, R.; Feldman, G.; Franz, B.; Frouin, R.; García-Soto, C.; Gibb, S.W.; Gould, R.; Hooker, S.; Kahru, M.; Klein, H.; Kratzer, S.; Loisel, H.; McKee, D.; Mitchell, B.G.; Moisan, T.; Muller-Karger, F.; O'Dowd, L.; Ondrusek, M.; Poulton, A.J.; Repecaud, M.; Smyth, T.; Sosik, H.M.; Taberner, M.; Twardowski, M.; Voss, K.; Werdell, J.; Wernand, M.; Zibordi, G. (2018): ESA Ocean Colour Climate Change Initiative (Ocean_Colour_cci): Version 3.1 Data. Centre for Environmental Data Analysis, 04 July 2018

esdc-2.1.1-high-res.description: The Cloud_cci project is generating long-term and coherent cloud property datasets, generated from the synergistic capabilities of multiple European and non-European Earth observation missions.  A centrepiece of this activity has been the development and application of two state-of-the-art physical retrieval systems that use the optimal estimation technique for a simultaneous, spectrally consistent retrieval of cloud properties including pixel-based uncertainty measures.

The Cloud_cci project is generating long-term and coherent cloud property datasets, generated from the synergistic capabilities of multiple European and non-European Earth observation missions.  A centrepiece of this activity has been the development and application of two state-of-the-art physical retrieval systems that use the optimal estimation technique for a simultaneous, spectrally consistent retrieval of cloud properties including pixel-based uncertainty measures.

esdc-2.1.1-high-res.project_name: ESA Greenhouse Gases Climate Change Initiative (GHG_cci)
esdc-2.1.1-high-res.long_name: Column Average Dry-air Mole Fraction Methane

esdc-2.1.1-high-res.project_name: ESA Greenhouse Gases Climate Change Initiative (GHG_cci)
esdc-2.1.1-high-res.long_name: Column Average Dry-air Mole Fraction Carbon Dioxide

esdc-2.1.1-high-res.project_name: ESA Land Cover Climate Change Initiative (Land_Cover_cci)
ESA Sea Surface Temperature Climate Change Initiative (SST_cci)
esdc-2.1.1-high-res.description: The Sea Surface Temperature (SST) project of the European Space Agency (ESA) Climate Change Initiative (CCI) Programme aims to make climate data records for SST longer, more stable and more accurate, providing data users with different forms of data and documentation.
esdc-2.1.1-high-res.references: Good, S.A.; Embury, O.; Bulgin, C.E.; Mittaz, J. (2019): ESA Sea Surface Temperature Climate Change Initiative (SST_cci): Level 4 Analysis Climate Data Record, version 2.1. Centre for Environmental Data Analysis, 22 August 2019. doi:10.5285/62c0f97b1eac4e0197a674870afe1ee6

esdc-2.1.1-high-res.project_name: ESA Sea Surface Temperature Climate Change Initiative (SST_cci)
esdc-2.1.1-high-res.description: The Sea Surface Temperature (SST) project of the European Space Agency (ESA) Climate Change Initiative (CCI) Programme aims to make climate data records for SST longer, more stable and more accurate, providing data users with different forms of data and documentation.

esdc-2.1.1-high-res.description: The ESA CCI soil moisture data combine various active and passive microwave sensors into a homogenized product. It represents the soil water content in the upper 5 cm of the soil, produced at a spatial sampling of 0.25° and a temporal sampling of 1 d. Gaps exist in periods of snow cover or frozen conditions and in areas with very dense vegetation.
esdc-2.1.1-high-res.references: Liu et al. (2012), Dorigo et al. (2017), Gruber et al. (2017)

esdc-2.1.1-high-res.description: By training an ensemble of machine learning algorithms with eddy covariance data from FLUXNET and satellite observations in a crossvalidation approach, regressions from these observations to different kinds of carbon and energy fluxes were established and used to generate data sets with a spatial resolution of 5 arcmin and a temporal resolution of 8 d. The GPP resembles the total carbon release of the ecosystem through respiration and is expressed in units of gC m^−2 d^−1.
esdc-2.1.1-high-res.references: Tramontana, G., Jung, M., Schwalm, C. R., Ichii, K., Camps-Valls, G., Ráduly, B., Reichstein, M., Arain, M. A., Cescatti, A., Kiely, G., Merbold, L., Serrano-Ortiz, P., Sickert, S., Wolf, S., and Papale, D.: Predicting carbon dioxide and energy fluxes across global FLUXNET sites with regression algorithms, Biogeosciences, 13, 4291–4313

esdc-2.1.1-high-res.description: By training an ensemble of machine learning algorithms with eddy covariance data from FLUXNET and satellite observations in a crossvalidation approach, regressions from these observations to different kinds of carbon and energy fluxes were established and used to generate data sets with a spatial resolution of 5 arcmin and a temporal resolution of 8 d. The LE resembles the latent heat flux from the surface and is expressed in units W m^−2.
esdc-2.1.1-high-res.references: Tramontana, G., Jung, M., Schwalm, C. R., Ichii, K., Camps-Valls, G., Ráduly, B., Reichstein, M., Arain, M. A., Cescatti, A., Kiely, G., Merbold, L., Serrano-Ortiz, P., Sickert, S., Wolf, S., and Papale, D.: Predicting carbon dioxide and energy fluxes across global FLUXNET sites with regression algorithms, Biogeosciences, 13, 4291–4313

esdc-2.1.1-high-res.description: By training an ensemble of machine learning algorithms with eddy covariance data from FLUXNET and satellite observations in a crossvalidation approach, regressions from these observations to different kinds of carbon and energy fluxes were established and used to generate data sets with a spatial resolution of 5 arcmin and a temporal resolution of 8 d. The NEE resembles the net carbon exchange between the ecosystem and the atmosphere and is expressed in units of gC m^−2 d^−1.
esdc-2.1.1-high-res.references: Tramontana, G., Jung, M., Schwalm, C. R., Ichii, K., Camps-Valls, G., Ráduly, B., Reichstein, M., Arain, M. A., Cescatti, A., Kiely, G., Merbold, L., Serrano-Ortiz, P., Sickert, S., Wolf, S., and Papale, D.: Predicting carbon dioxide and energy fluxes across global FLUXNET sites with regression algorithms, Biogeosciences, 13, 4291–4313

esdc-2.1.1-high-res.description: By training an ensemble of machine learning algorithms with eddy covariance data from FLUXNET and satellite observations in a crossvalidation approach, regressions from these observations to different kinds of carbon and energy fluxes were established and used to generate data sets with a spatial resolution of 5 arcmin and a temporal resolution of 8 d. The NEE resembles the net carbon exchange between the ecosystem and the atmosphere and is expressed in units of gC m^−2 d^−1.
esdc-2.1.1-high-res.references: Tramontana, G., Jung, M., Schwalm, C. R., Ichii, K., Camps-Valls, G., Ráduly, B., Reichstein, M., Arain, M. A., Cescatti, A., Kiely, G., Merbold, L., Serrano-Ortiz, P., Sickert, S., Wolf, S., and Papale, D.: Predicting carbon dioxide and energy fluxes across global FLUXNET sites with regression algorithms, Biogeosciences, 13, 4291–4313

esdc-2.1.1-high-res.description: By training an ensemble of machine learning algorithms with eddy covariance data from FLUXNET and satellite observations in a crossvalidation approach, regressions from these observations to different kinds of carbon and energy fluxes were established and used to generate data sets with a spatial resolution of 5 arcmin and a temporal resolution of 8 d. The H resembles the sensible heat flux from the surface and is expressed in units of W m^−2.
esdc-2.1.1-high-res.references: Tramontana, G., Jung, M., Schwalm, C. R., Ichii, K., Camps-Valls, G., Ráduly, B., Reichstein, M., Arain, M. esdc-2.1.1-high-res.description: By training an ensemble of machine learning algorithms with eddy covariance data from FLUXNET and satellite observations in a crossvalidation approach, regressions from these observations to different kinds of carbon and energy fluxes were established and used to generate data sets with a spatial resolution of 5 arcmin and a temporal resolution of 8 d. The H resembles the sensible heat flux from the surface and is expressed in units of W m^−2.
esdc-2.1.1-high-res.references: Tramontana, G., Jung, M., Schwalm, C. R., Ichii, K., Camps-Valls, G., Ráduly, B., Reichstein, M., Arain, M. A., Cescatti, A., Kiely, G., Merbold, L., Serrano-Ortiz, P., Sickert, S., Wolf, S., and Papale, D.: Predicting carbon dioxide and energy fluxes across global FLUXNET sites with regression algorithms, Biogeosciences, 13, 4291–4313

esdc-2.1.1-high-res.description: This data set was taken from the fourth generation of the Global Fire Emissions Database (GFED4). It was created as a combination of data from infrared sensor satellite observations and resembles the estimated monthly burnt area in hectares. The spatial resolution of this data set is 0.25°. Small fires were exempt in the production of the data.
esdc-2.1.1-high-res.references: Giglio, L., Randerson, J. T., and van der Werf, G. R., (2013), Analysis of daily, monthly, and annual burned area using the fourth-generation global fire emissions database (GFED4) J. Geophys. Res. Biogeosci., 118, 317– 328

esdc-2.1.1-high-res.long_name: Carbon dioxide emissions due to natural fires expressed as carbon flux
esdc-2.1.1-high-res.description: This data set was taken from the fourth generation of the Global Fire Emissions Database (GFED4). It was created as a combination of data from infrared sensor satellite observations and resembles the estimated monthly burnt area in hectares. The spatial resolution of this data set is 0.25°. Small fires were exempt in the production of the data.
esdc-2.1.1-high-res.references: Giglio, L., Randerson, J. T., and van der Werf, G. R., (2013), Analysis of daily, monthly, and annual burned area using the fourth-generation global fire emissions database (GFED4) J. Geophys. Res. Biogeosci., 118, 317– 328

esdc-2.1.1-high-res.description: The GLEAM data sets are created by using a set of algorithms, input forcing data sets from reanalyses, optical and microwave satellites, and other merged sources. The model itself consists of four modules: potential evaporation (Priestley–Taylor equation), interception (Gash analytical model), soil (multilayer soil model plus data assimilation), and stress (semiempirical). The data are sampled on a graticule of 0.25° and have a daily temporal coverage.
esdc-2.1.1-high-res.references: Martens et al. (2017), Miralles et al. (2011)

esdc-2.1.1-high-res.description: The GLEAM data sets are created by using a set of algorithms, input forcing data sets from reanalyses, optical and microwave satellites, and other merged sources. The model itself consists of four modules: potential evaporation (Priestley–Taylor equation), interception (Gash analytical model), soil (multilayer soil model plus data assimilation), and stress (semiempirical). The data are sampled on a graticule of 0.25° and have a daily temporal coverage.

esdc-2.1.1-high-res.long_name: Black Sky Albedo for Visible Wavebands
esdc-2.1.1-high-res.description: Black-sky albedo, also known as directional– hemispherical reflectance (only direct illumination), estimated from satellite radiometer data. The spatial resolution of this product is 1 km with a temporal sampling of 8 d.
esdc-2.1.1-high-res.references: P. Lewis et al., The ESA globAlbedo project: Algorithm 2012 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium, 2012, pp. 5745-5748

esdc-2.1.1-high-res.long_name: White Sky Albedo for Visible Wavebands
esdc-2.1.1-high-res.description: White-sky albedo, also known as bihemispherical reflectance (only diffuse illumination), estimated from satellite radiometer data. The spatial resolution of this product is 1 km with a temporal sampling of 8 d.
esdc-2.1.1-high-res.references: P. Lewis et al., The ESA globAlbedo project: Algorithm 2012 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium, 2012, pp. 5745-5748

esdc-2.1.1-high-res.description: Global fractional snow cover product using mainly satellite infrared radiometer data (ATSR-2, AATSR). Glaciers, continental ice shields, and snow on ice are exempt from the data. Values stand for the percentage of the area of a grid cell covered by snow integrated over time (daily, weekly, or monthly). The spatial resolution is 1 km.
esdc-2.1.1-high-res.references: Takala, M., Luojus, K., Pulliainen, J., Derksen, C., Lemmetyinen, J., Kärnä, J.-P, Koskinen, J., Bojkov, B., “Estimating northern hemisphere snow water equivalent for climate research through assimilation of spaceborne radiometer data and ground-based measurements”, Remote Sensing of Environment, Vol. 115, Issue 12, 15 December 2011, doi: 10.1016/j.rse.2011.08.014

esdc-2.1.1-high-res.description: Snow water equivalent product covering the Northern Hemisphere (35–85° N), created by using microwave sensor data (SMMR, SSM/I, SSMIS). Glaciers, continental ice shields, and mountainous regions are exempt from the data. Values stand for the water equivalent of snow per grid cell in millimetres aggregated over time (daily, weekly, or monthly). The weekly data are produced by giving every day the mean value of a sliding window (−6 d). The monthly data are given as the weekly mean and maximum per calendar month. The spatial resolution is approximately 25 km.
esdc-2.1.1-high-res.references: Takala, M., Luojus, K., Pulliainen, J., Derksen, C., Lemmetyinen, J., Kärnä, J.-P, Koskinen, J., Bojkov, B., “Estimating northern hemisphere snow water equivalent for climate research through assimilation of spaceborne radiometer data and ground-based measurements”, Remote Sensing of Environment, Vol. 115, Issue 12, 15 December 2011, doi: 10.1016/j.rse.2011.08.014

esdc-2.1.1-high-res.description: The GlobTemperature Land Surface Temperature product used here is a product of a satellite infrared radiometer (AATSR). It has global coverage with a spatial sampling of 0.05° and consists of two measurement averages (day and night). The values are an approximation of the average land surface temperature per grid cell in K. It is an improved version of the ESA AATSR data set (UOL_LST_3P, v2.1).
esdc-2.1.1-high-res.references: Ghent, D. (2012). Land Surface Temperature Validation and Algorithm Verification (Report to European Space Agency).

esdc-2.1.1-high-res.description: The TCWV product was derived through combination of various satellite spectrometer and microwave sensor data sets. It resembles the total mass of water contained in a column of air from the surface to 200 hPa. The unit is kg m^−2, the spatial sampling is 0.5°, and the data are provided as daily composites. From 1996 to 2002 (inclusive), the data consist of weekly/monthly means.
esdc-2.1.1-high-res.references: Schröder et al. (2012), Schneider et al. (2013)

esdc-2.1.1-high-res.description: The Global Precipitation Climatology Project (GPCP)
esdc-2.1.1-high-res.references: Adler et al. (2003), Huffman et al. (2009)

esdc-2.1.1-high-res.long_name: Mean total ozone column in dobson units
esdc-2.1.1-high-res.description: The total ozone column data from the Ozone CCI project is derived from the Global Ozone Monitoring Experiment (GOME) spectrometer acquisitions. For the ESDL, level 2 data have been used. They are given in Dobson units (DU) and have a spatial resolution of 320 km× 40 km. The temporal resolution depends on the latitude, with the longest revisit time being 3 d at the Equator.
esdc-2.1.1-high-res.references: Van Roozendael et al. (2012), Lerot et al. (2014)

esdc-2.1.1-high-res.long_name: Fraction of Absorbed Photosynthetically Active Radiation
esdc-2.1.1-high-res.long_name_pdf: Fraction of absorbed photo- synthetically active radiation
esdc-2.1.1-high-res.description: The fAPAR, describing the amount and productivity of vegetation, was derived by using a twostream inversion package (TIP) method based on the two-stream model developed by Pinty et al. (2006). The product is delivered in two spatial resolutions (0.05 and 0.5°) and with a daily temporal coverage.
esdc-2.1.1-high-res.references: Disney et al. (2016), Blessing and Löw (2017)

esdc-2.1.1-high-res.description: The LAI, defined as half the total canopy area per unit ground area (m^2 m^−2), was derived by using a TIP method based on the two-stream model developed by Pinty et al. (2006). The product is delivered in two spatial resolutions (0.05 and 0.5°) and with a daily temporal coverage.
esdc-2.1.1-high-res.references: Disney et al. (2016), Blessing and Löw (2017)

esdc-2.1.1-high-res.long_name: Directional Hemisphere Reflectance albedo - VIS band
esdc-2.1.1-high-res.long_name_pdf: Black-sky albedo for visible wavelengths from AVHRR
esdc-2.1.1-high-res.description: Black-sky albedo, also known as directional– hemispherical reflectance (only direct illumination), estimated from satellite radiometer data. This data set extends the GlobAlbedo data by using additional input data sources (AVHRR, geostationary satellites). The product is delivered in two spatial resolutions (0.05 and 0.5°) and with a daily temporal coverage.
esdc-2.1.1-high-res.references: Lewis et al. (2012), Danne et al. (2017)

esdc-2.1.1-high-res.long_name_pdf: White-sky albedo for visible wavelengths from AVHRR
esdc-2.1.1-high-res.description: White-sky albedo, also known as bihemispherical reflectance (only diffuse illumination), estimated from satellite radiometer data. This data set extends the GlobAlbedo data by using additional input data sources (Advanced Very High Resolution Radiometer (AVHRR), geostationary satellites). The product is delivered in two spatial resolutions (0.05 and 0.5°) and with a daily temporal coverage.
esdc-2.1.1-high-res.references: Lewis et al. (2012), Danne et al. (2017)

esdc-3.0.2.project_name: ESA Soil Moisture Climate Change Initiative
ESA Soil Moisture Climate Change Initiative
